Posted: December 8, 2013
												Insurgency is what other big budget shooters should try to be like. It's based more around strategy and good decision making than killstreaks or explosions (as it should be). This makes IMIC feel more like a classic military simulator among the likes of the original Rainbow Six or early Ghost Recon games, than Call of Duty or Battlefield. Even though death comes quickly and respawns are slow, I never felt frusturated because when I died I usually felt it was my own fault rather than cheap game design. I don't think I will be playing it for years on end like Counter Strike or TF2, mainly because there isn't a whole lot of content or support for it, but it certainly is worth playing at least a few times. While it is relatively simple (compared to most modern shooters) , it's alot of fun, especially since it's free.

												A nice Game i can say...It's like Call of Duty: Modern Warfare.You can take it,it's free,that is the best part.A Counter-Strike Free!Ok,now let's talk about the Game.INSURGENCY: Modern Infantry Combat is primarily a team-based, multiplayer online shooter focused on tactical, objective-based gameplay. The player can join one of two teams, the US Marines, or their adversaries, the Insurgents. Teams are structured around two squads, for a total of 16 maximum players per team. Within this team structure are limited player classes, such as the Rifleman, Support Gunner, Engineer, or Marksman.The game has a pseudo-realistic portrayal of the weaponry used. There is no on-screen crosshair and the players must use the iron sights of the game's weapon model to accurately aim the weapon. Shooting "from the hip" is still possible; however, the free-aim system makes this difficult. Weapons are also deadly, with most rifles capable of taking out players with one or two shots to the torso. According to their class, players can also use fragmentation grenades, smoke grenades, and RPGs.Maps are generally focused on urban warfare, even though there are suburban and outdoor settings.

Posted: December 26, 2010
												INSURGENCY: MIC is a decent HL2 mod that has recently been rebuilt as it's own standalone game.  Back around 2010 was arguably the glory days of MIC.  Back then, there were always servers up and running, and active clans, and a great community.  However, as time went on, more people seemed to stop playing, and client-side modding became more prevalent.  This game became ruined as a material hack became popular and more servers failed to enforce sv_pure 1.I'd say that less than 100 people are ever on at once.  Very few servers are ever populated, and even then they're eastern European servers with bad latency and a lacking community.  This mod is dying but hopefully it will live on in the standalone.The game itself isn't too shabby.  There's Marines and Iraqi insurgents.  Each team has two squads, and each team has a few specialty weapons such as the RPG-7 or M16 with grenade launcher.  The game comes with maps that are all well made and provide a good atmosphere.  A fairly popular map was a rehash of de_dust2 from CS:S.  Weapons damage is more realistic, and there's no crosshairs.  The game is more immersive than Counter-Strike: Source and typical last-gen FPS games.  7/10 for nostalgia, but I'm not going to sink any more time into this one.

												Insurgency is a multiplayer, tactical first person shooter. It implements elements of realism, in an attempt to increase player immersion and promote teamwork. The game is primarily set in Iraq, however some maps are set in Afghanistan.There are two teams available, the US Marines and the Insurgents. Teams are structured around two squads, for a total of 16 maximum players per team. Within this team structure are limited player classes, such as the Rifleman, Support Gunner, Engineer or Marksman.There is no on-screen crosshair and the players must use the iron sights of the game's weapon model to accurately aim the weapon. The maps are small but this does not mean that there is no tactics involved. Insurgency: Modern Infantry Combat is one of the most realistic source mods out there. At the beginning it is hard but once you play for a few hours, you start to get the hang of it. Posted: January 9, 2014
												The underlying mechanics of this game are solid and the more "realistic" approach is certainly appreciated as it actually does require you to make some tactical considerations, however the game undermines itself in a pretty severe way. And that is the maps themselves. They are still designed around more arcade style shooters, and so what you often find happening is that there is never a defensible point, and no choke points to have any sort of firefight. Inevitably every public match will end up becoming a sort of free for all death match where players sprint around the levels hoping to get the drop on an unsuspecting opponent. The most fun I have had with this mod was when it was more popular and people where running counterstrike source maps in it. Those maps actually had good design philosphy and worked especially well with the shooting mechanics in this game. As insurgency stands now though, I cannot recommend it. It is an oddity, the parts that work, work really well, but it is unfortunate that the developers never bothered to create functional maps. If they had I suspect the community would have stuck around.

												I've only played maybe half an hour of this game, but I can already see plenty of problems. The main menu is incredibly bland. Don't hope to sit in the menu and hope to do anything other than mess with your options, because so far no character loadouts or anything of the like has been added. And the fog of war doesn't help you see enemies that keep picking you off from 30 yards away. This game does have some redeeming features, like playing as the sergeant you can issue commands. And there are smoke grenades. But they have a rather small effect. All of the movement controls are definitely a plus. Lean, crouch, prone, sprint... All in all, this is a decent game and with a bit more of a following or a few more servers up, who knows... the devs might make a few tweaks and this game will become a success. But as is, it's very rough around the edges.
